content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE metadata SYSTEM "http://thor-f5.er.usgs.gov/ngtoc/metadata/fgdc-std-001-1998.dtd"> <metadata>   <idinfo>     <citation>       <citeinfo>         <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>         <pubdate>200304</pubdate>         <title>USGS Small-scale Dataset - Color North America Shaded Relief - 1-Kilometer Resolution 200304 GeoTIFF</title>         <edition>3</edition>         <geoform>Map</geoform>         <pubinfo>           <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>           <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>         </pubinfo>         <onlink>http://dds.cr.usgs.gov/pub/data/nationalatlas/shdrlfi020l_nt00031.tar.gz</onlink>         <lworkcit>           <citeinfo>             <origin>U.S. Geological Survey</origin>             <pubdate>2005</pubdate>             <title>Small-scale Datasets</title>             <onlink>https://www.sciencebase.gov/catalog/item/532c5b23e4b0cd7393d07783</onlink>           </citeinfo>         </lworkcit>       </citeinfo>     </citation>     <descript>       <abstract> The North America Shaded Relief data were derived from the GTOPO30  elevation data.  GTOPO30 is a global digital elevation model (DEM) with  a horizontal grid spacing of 30 arc seconds (approximately 1 kilometer).  GTOPO30 was derived from several raster and vector sources of  topographic information.  It was developed between 1993 and 1996 through  a collaborative effort led by staff at the U.S. Geological Survey's EROS  Data Center (EDC).  The following organizations participated by  contributing funding or source data: the National Aeronautics and Space  Administration (NASA), the United Nations Environment Programme/Global  Resource Information Database (UNEP/GRID), the U.S. Agency for  International Development (USAID), the Instituto Nacional de Estadistica  Geografica e Informatica (INEGI) of Mexico, the Geographical Survey  Institute (GSI) of Japan, Manaaki Whenua Landcare Research of New  Zealand, and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR).  This  file is a replacement for the January 2003 map layer.  This map layer was  previously distributed as North America Shaded Relief.  </abstract>       <purpose> The Shaded Relief image was developed to portray the terrain of North  America.  It is intended for visual purposes only.  The original GTOPO30  data must be used for conducting analysis and determining elevation  values.  </purpose>       <supplinf> The associated world file is included as part of the GeoTIFF.  The  contents of the world file are:  >1000.0000  >0.000000  >0.000000  >-1000.0000  >-6086129.0000  >4488261.0000    The following projection file can be used when using ESRI's ArcGIS to view  the        </rngdates>           </timeinfo>           <srccurr>Dates of the elevation data</srccurr>         </srctime>         <srccitea>Elevation2002</srccitea>         <srccontr>Elevation information.</srccontr>       </srcinfo>       <procstep>         <procdesc> The mosaic of elevation data used for North America Shaded Relief was  first assembled in 1999 for use on the National Atlas web site, and for  a printed map at 1:10,000,000 scale published that same year.  The  original 1999 map layer was assembled from the following tiles of  GTOPO30 elevation data: w180n90, w140n90, w100n90, w060n90, w020n90,  w180n40, w140n40, w100n40, w060n40, w020n40.  The tiles were ingested  into Arc/INFO with the IMAGEGRID command.  The resulting grids were  combined into a single grid with the MERGE function.  This grid was then  projected into the Lambert Azimuthal Equal Area projection, centered on  100 degrees West, 45 degrees North.  The .prj file used for the Arc  PROJECT command contained these parameters:  > INPUT  > PROJECTION GEOGRAPHIC  > UNITS DD  > PARAMETERS  > OUTPUT  > PROJECTION LAMBERT_AZIMUTHAL  > UNITS METERS  > XSHIFT 0.0  > YSHIFT 0.0  > PARAMETERS  > 0.0  > -100 0 0  > 45 0 0  > 0.0  > 0.0  > END  >  The western edge of the grid was extended to match that of the National  Atlas of the United States Map Maker bounding rectangle, and the null  cells in the extended area were converted to ocean RGB values using CON.  </procdesc>         <srcused>GTOPO30</srcused>         <procdate>1999</procdate>         <srcprod>Elevation1999</srcprod>       </procstep>       <procstep>         <procdesc> The color shaded relief rendition was created by combining two files:  1. File one was a color elevation image, created by slicing the  corrected elevation data using the ranges (listed in feet; divide by  3.2808 to get meters) and RGB color values below.  This image file was  converted in Adobe Photoshop from RGB to CMY (no black generated).    >From    To     index     red     green   blue  >===================================================  >-250    0      1         215     215     215  >1       249    2         113     153     89  >250     499    3         117     170     101  >500     999    4         149     190     113  >1000    1499   5         178     214     117  >1500    1999   6         202     226     149  >2000    2499   7         222     238     161  >2500    2999   8         242     238     161  >3000    3499   9         238     222     153  >3500    3999   10        242     206     133  >4000    4499   11        234     182     129  >4500    4999   12        218     157     121  >5000    5499   13        194     141     125  >5500    5999   14        214     157     145  >6000    6499   15        226     174     165  >6500    6999   16        222     186     182  >7000    7499   17        238     198     210  >7500    7999   18        255     206     226  >8000    8499   19        250     218     234  >8500    8999   20        255     222     230  >9000    9499   21        255     230     242  >9500    9999   22        255     242     255  >10000   19476  23        255     255     255  >Water          24        132     193     255  >    2. File two was a grayscale shaded relief rendition of the elevation  data, created with the Grid HILLSHADE command using these parameters:  >azimuth = 315 degrees  >sun elevation = 45 degrees  >Shadetype = SHADE  >Vertical exaggeration = 10.0  File two was added as a black (K) band to file one (CMY), to create a  CMYK color shaded relief image.  Overall contrast was enhanced and  excessive shading around lake boundaries was lightened, then the CMYK  image was converted in Photoshop to RGB for use in the online National  Atlas.    The file was converted to TIFF format using the command GRIDIMAGE to  create the final TIFF file, Shdrlfi020l.tif with an accompanying .tfw  world file.  </procdesc>         <srcused>Elevation1999</srcused>         <procdate>1999</procdate>         <srcprod>Shade1999</srcprod>       </procstep>       <procstep>         <procdesc> In 2001 and 2002, some areas of the elevation mosaic were updated with  improved data provided as internal files by science staff at EROS Data  Center.  The first update, in October, 2001 featured two significant  improvements:  1. Much of the GTOPO30 coverage of the conterminous  United States was updated from higher resolution elevation data from the  National Elevation Dataset;  2. Parts of northern Canada were corrected  to remove a processing artifact that created an artificial pattern of  "dimples" in the shaded relief.  These elevation data were used for a  printed National Atlas product, the 2002 "Shaded Relief of North  America" map published at 1:10,000,000 scale.    In the second update, in September, 2002, data for Greenland were  entirely replaced by a higher resolution dataset that, however, suffered  from geometric distortion.  These new data for Greenland were adjusted  to correct for geometric distortion in the northwest part of the island  between the Robeson Channel and Cape Morris Jesup, and to improve  registration with the coastline derived from World Vector Shoreline  (WVS).  A link coverage was created in ArcEdit containing links between  the original Greenland data and the new coastline.  The link coverage  was used in the Arc ADJUST command to perform a linear transformation  with bilinear resampling on the original image, stored as an Arc/INFO  grid dataset.  The resulting image is geometrically correct and fits the  WVS coastline.  This correction was applied to data for Greenland only.  </procdesc>         <srcused>Elevation1999</srcused>         <srcused>2001 Update</srcused>         <srcused>2002 Update</srcused>         <srcused>National Elevation Dataset</srcused>         <srcused>WVS</srcused>         <procdate>200212</procdate>         <srcprod>Elevation2002</srcprod>       </procstep>       <procstep>         <procdesc> The color shaded relief rendition was created by combining two files:  1. File one was a color elevation image, created by slicing the  corrected elevation data using the ranges (listed in feet; divide by  3.2808 to get meters) and RGB color values below.  This image file was  converted in Adobe Photoshop from RGB to CMY (no black generated).    >From    To     index     red     green   blue  >===================================================  >-250    0      1         215     215     215  >1       249    2         113     153     89  >250     499    3         117     170     101  >500     999    4         149     190     113  >1000    1499   5         178     214     117  >1500    1999   6         202     226     149  >2000    2499   7         222     238     161  >2500    2999   8         242     238     161  >3000    3499   9         238     222     153  >3500    3999   10        242     206     133  >4000    4499   11        234     182     129  >4500    4999   12        218     157     121  >5000    5499   13        194     141     125  >5500    5999   14        214     157     145  >6000    6499   15        226     174     165  >6500    6999   16        222     186     182  >7000    7499   17        238     198     210  >7500    7999   18        255     206     226  >8000    8499   19        250     218     234  >8500    8999   20        255     222     230  >9000    9499   21        255     230     242  >9500    9999   22        255     242     255  >10000   19476  23        255     255     255  >Water          24        132     193     255  >    2. File two was a grayscale shaded relief rendition of the elevation  data, created with the Grid HILLSHADE command using these parameters:  >azimuth = 315 degrees  >sun elevation = 45 degrees  >Shadetype = SHADE  >Vertical exaggeration = 10.0  File two was added as a black (K) band to file one (CMY), to create a  CMYK color shaded relief image.  Overall contrast was enhanced and  excessive shading around lake boundaries was lightened, then the CMYK  image was converted in Photoshop to RGB for use in the online National  Atlas.    This image contains color shaded relief in RGB color space.  For access  to its sliced elevation and grayscale shaded relief components, or to  the original 16-bit DEM data (Elevation2002), please contact the  National Atlas.    These same elevation data were also used for a printed National Atlas  product, the 2002 "Shaded Relief of North America" map published at  1:10,000,000 scale.  Updated source data and intermediate products, as  well as the final color shaded relief image (in CMYK) used on the  printed map, are also available from the National Atlas.  </procdesc>         <srcused>Elevation2002</srcused>         <procdate>200212</procdate>       </procstep>     </lineage>   </dataqual>   <spdoinfo>     <direct>Raster</direct>     <rastinfo>       <rasttype>Grid
